Package parsii.eval

Class Scope

java.lang.Object
parsii.eval.Scope
public class Scope
extends java.lang.Object
Contains a mapping of names to variables.

Both the user as well as the Parser use a Scope to resolve a name into a Variable. In contrast to a simple Map, this approach provides two advantages: It's usually faster, as the variable only needs to be resolved once. Modifying it and especially reading it when evaluating an expression is as cheap as a simple field access. The second advantage is that scopes can be chained. So variables can be either shared by two expression or kept separate, if required.

  • Constructor Summary

    Constructors 
    Constructor Description
    Scope()
    Creates a new empty scope.

  • Constructor Details

    • Scope

      public Scope()
      Creates a new empty scope.

      The scope will not be completely empty, as Math.PI (pi) and Math.E (E) are always defined as constants.

      If an not yet known variable is accessed, it will be created and initialized with 0.

  • Method Details

    • withStrictLookup

      public Scope withStrictLookup​(boolean strictLookup)
      Determines if strict lookup should be used or not.

      A scope with strict lookup will not create unknown variables upon their first access but rather throw an error.

      By default, scopes are not strict and will automatically create variables when first reuqested.

      Parameters:
      strictLookup - true if the scope should be switched to strict lookup, false otherwise
      Returns:
      the instance itself for fluent method calls

    • withParent

      public Scope withParent​(Scope parent)
      Specifies the parent scope for this scope.

      If a scope cannot resolve a variable, it tries to resolve it using its parent scope. This permits to share a certain set of variables.

      Parameters:
      parent - the parent scope to use. If null, the common root scope is used which defines a bunch of constants (e and pi).
      Returns:
      the instance itself for fluent method calls

    • find

      public Variable find​(java.lang.String name)
      Searches for a Variable with the given name.

      If the variable does not exist null will be returned

      Parameters:
      name - the name of the variable to search
      Returns:
      the variable with the given name or null if no such variable was found

    • getVariable

      public Variable getVariable​(java.lang.String name)
      Searches for or creates a variable with the given name.

      If no variable with the given name is found, a new variable is created in this scope

      Parameters:
      name - the variable to look for
      Returns:
      a variable with the given name
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if autocreateVariables is false and the given variable was not creted yet.

    • create

      public Variable create​(java.lang.String name)
      Searches or creates a variable in this scope.

      Tries to find a variable with the given name in this scope. If no variable with the given name is found, the parent scope is not checked, but a new variable is created.

      Parameters:
      name - the variable to search or create
      Returns:
      a variable with the given name from the local scope

    • remove

      public Variable remove​(java.lang.String name)
      Removes the variable with the given name from this scope.

      If will not remove the variable from a parent scope.

      Parameters:
      name - the name of the variable to remove
      Returns:
      the removed variable or null if no variable with the given name existed

    • getLocalNames

      public java.util.Set<java.lang.String> getLocalNames()
      Returns all names of variables known to this scope (ignoring those of the parent scope).
      Returns:
      a set of all known variable names

    • getNames

      public java.util.Set<java.lang.String> getNames()
      Returns all names of variables known to this scope or one of its parent scopes.
      Returns:
      a set of all known variable names

    • getLocalVariables

      public java.util.Collection<Variable> getLocalVariables()
      Returns all variables known to this scope (ignoring those of the parent scope).
      Returns:
      a collection of all known variables

    • getVariables

      public java.util.Collection<Variable> getVariables()
      Returns all variables known to this scope or one of its parent scopes.
      Returns:
      a collection of all known variables
